standard_metadata.standard_description: Explain patterns in the number of zeros of the product when multiplying a number by powers of 10, and explain patterns in the placement of the decimal point when a decimal is multiplied or divided by a power of 10. Use whole-number exponents to denote powers of 10.
standard_metadata.standard_title: Multiply and divide by powers of 10

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

$\begin{align} &32.689\times\blueD{10^1} = 32.689\times\blueD {10}\\\\ &32.689\times\greenD{10^2} = 32.689\times\greenD {10\times10}\\\\ &32.689\times\purpleC{10^3} = 32.689\times\purpleC {10\times10\times10} \end{align}$
Multiplying by ${10}$ moves every digit **one place to the left**.     Drag the dot all the way to the right.   [[☃ interaction 2]]
So, if we multiply by ${10}$ $\greenD{\text{two}}$ times, we move every digit **$\greenD{\text{two}}$ places to the left.**

Let's look at how the pattern continues.     | | | |  -: | -: | :-: | -: | :-: | -: $32.689\times\blueD{10^1} = $ |$32.689\times\blueD{10}$ | $=$ | $326.89$ $32.689\times\greenD{10^2} = $ |$32.689\times\greenD{10\times10}$ | $=$ | $3268.9\phantom{0}$ $32.689\times\purpleC{10^3} = $ |$32.689\times\purpleC{10\times10\times10}$ | $=$ | $32{,}689\phantom{.00}$
Here are the completed equations:  $\begin{align} &32.689 \times 10^1 =326.89\\\\ &32.689 \times 10^2 =3268.9\\\\ &32.689 \times 10^3 =32{,}689 \end{align}$

###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

$\begin{align} &0.258\times\greenD{10^2} = 0.258\times\greenD {10\times10}\\\\ &0.258\times\purpleC{10^3} = 0.258\times\purpleC {10\times10\times10}\\\\ &0.258\times\maroonD{10^4} = 0.258\times\maroonD {10\times10\times10\times10} \end{align}$
Multiplying by ${10}$ moves every digit one place to the left.    Drag the  dot all the way to the right.    [[☃ interaction 2]]
So, if we multiply by ${10}$ $\greenD{\text{two}}$ times, we move every digit **$\greenD{\text{two}}$ places to the left.**

Let's look at how the pattern continues.     | | | | -: | -: | :-: | -: | :-: | -: $0.258\times\blueD{10^1} = $ |$0.258\times\blueD{10}$ | $=$ | $2.58$ $0.258\times\greenD{10^2} = $ |$0.258\times\greenD{10\times10}$ | $=$ | $25.8\phantom{0}$ $0.258\times\purpleC{10^3} = $ |$0.258\times\purpleC{10\times10\times10}$ | $=$ | $258\phantom{.00}$ $0.258\times\maroonD{10^4} = $ |$0.258\times\maroonD{10\times10\times10\times10}$ | $=$ | $2580\phantom{.00}$
Here are the completed equations:  $\begin{align} &0.258 \times 10^2 =25.8\\\\ &0.258 \times 10^3 =258\\\\ &0.258 \times 10^4 = 2{,}580 \end{align}$

###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

$\begin{align} &95\times\purpleC{10^3} = 95\times\purpleC {10\times10\times10}\\\\ &95\times\maroonD{10^4} = 95\times\maroonD {10\times10\times10\times10}\\\\ &95\times\goldD{10^5} = 95\times\goldD {10\times10\times10\times10\times10} \end{align}$
Multiplying by ${10}$ moves every digit one place to the left.    Drag the dot all the way to the right.    [[☃ interaction 7]]    *Notice we add a zero in the empty place value.*
So, if we multiply by ${10}$ $\purpleC{\text{three}}$ times, we move every digit **$\purpleC{\text{three}}$ places to the left.**

Let's look at how the pattern continues.     | | | |  -: | -: | :-: | -: | :-: | -: $95\times\blueD{10^1} = $ |$95\times\blueD{10}$ | $=$ | $95\blueD{0}$ $95\times\greenD{10^2} = $ |$95\times\greenD{10\times10}$ | $=$ | $9{,}5\greenD{00}$ $95\times\purpleC{10^3} = $ |$95\times\purpleC{10\times10\times10}$ | $=$ | $95{,}\purpleC{000}$ $95\times\maroonD{10^4} = $ |$95\times\maroonD{10\times10\times10\times10}$ | $=$ | $95\maroonD{0{,}000}$ $95\times\goldD{10^5} = $ |$95\times\goldD{10\times10\times10\times10\times10}$ | $=$ | $9{,}5\goldD{00{,}000}$
Here are the completed equations:  $\begin{align} &95\times 10^3 = 95{,}000\\\\ &95\times 10^4 =950{,}000\\\\  &95\times 10^5 = 9{,}500{,}000 \end{align}$

###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

$\begin{align} &29.1\times\purpleC{10^3} = 29.1\times\purpleC {10\times10\times10}\\\\ &29.1\times\maroonD{10^4} = 29.1\times\maroonD {10\times10\times10\times10}\\\\ &29.1\times\goldD{10^5} = 29.1\times\goldD {10\times10\times10\times10\times10} \end{align}$
Multiplying by ${10}$ moves every digit one place to the left.     Drag the dot all the way to the right.    [[☃ interaction 1]]
So, if we multiply by ${10}$ $\purpleC{\text{three}}$ times, we move every digit **$\purpleC{\text{three}}$ places to the left.**

Let's look at how the pattern continues.     | | | |  -: | -: | :-: | -: | :-: | -: $29.1\times\blueD{10^1} = $ |$29.1\times\blueD{10}$ | $=$ | $291$ $29.1\times\greenD{10^2} = $ |$29.1\times\greenD{10\times10}$ | $=$ | $2{,}910$ $29.1\times\purpleC{10^3} = $ |$29.1\times\purpleC{10\times10\times10}$ | $=$ | $29{,}100$ $29.1\times\maroonD{10^4} = $ |$29.1\times\maroonD{10\times10\times10\times10}$ | $=$ | $291{,}000$ $29.1\times\goldD{10^5} = $ |$29.1\times\goldD{10\times10\times10\times10\times10}$ | $=$ | $2{,}910{,}000$
Here are the completed equations:  $\begin{align} &29.1 \times 10^3 =29{,}100\\\\ &29.1 \times 10^4 =291{,}000\\\\ &29.1 \times 10^5 =2{,}910{,}000 \end{align}$

###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

$\begin{align} &28{,}770\div\greenD{10^2} = 28{,}770\div\greenD {10\div10}\\\\ &28{,}770\div\purpleC{10^3} = 28{,}770\div\purpleC {10\div10\div10}\\\\ &28{,}770\div\maroonD{10^4} = 28{,}770\div\maroonD {10\div10\div10\div10} \end{align}$
Dividing by ${10}$ moves every digit one place to the right.    Drag the dot all the way to the right.    [[☃ interaction 1]]
So, if we divide by ${10}$ $\greenD{\text{two}}$ times, we move every digit **$\greenD{\text{two}}$ places to the right.**
Here are the completed equations:  $\begin{align} &28{,}770\div 10^2 =287.7\\\\ &28{,}770\div 10^3 =28.77\\\\ &28{,}770\div 10^4 =2.877 \end{align}$

###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

$\begin{align} &64{,}000\div\purpleC{10^3} = 64{,}000\div\purpleC {10\div10\div10}\\\\ &64{,}000\div\maroonD{10^4} = 64{,}000\div\maroonD {10\div10\div10\div10}\\\\ &64{,}000\div\goldD{10^5} = 64{,}000\div\goldD {10\div10\div10\div10\div10} \end{align}$
Dividing by ${10}$ moves every digit one place to the right.    Drag the dot all the way to the right.    [[☃ interaction 1]]
So, if we divide by ${10}$ $\purpleC{\text{three}}$ times, we move every digit **$\purpleC{\text{three}}$ places to the right.**
Here are the completed equations:  $\begin{align} &64{,}000\div 10^3 =64\\\\ &64{,}000\div 10^4 =6.4\\\\  &64{,}000\div 10^5 =0.64 \end{align}$

###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

$\begin{align} &4{,}502\div\blueD{10^1} = 4{,}502\div\blueD {10}\\\\ &4{,}502\div\greenD{10^2} = 4{,}502\div\greenD {10\div10}\\\\ &4{,}502\div\purpleC{10^3} = 4{,}502\div\purpleC {10\div10\div10} \end{align}$
Dividing by ${10}$ moves every digit one place to the right.    Drag the dot all the way to the right.    [[☃ interaction 1]]
So, if we divide by ${10}$ $\greenD{\text{two}}$ times, we move every digit **$\greenD{\text{two}}$ places to the right.**
Here are the completed equations:  $\begin{align} &4{,}502\div 10^1 =450.2\\\\   &4{,}502\div 10^2 =45.02\\\\ &4{,}502\div 10^3 =4.502 \end{align}$

###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$

$\begin{align} &72{,}910\div\greenD{10^2} = 72{,}910\div\greenD {10\div10}\\\\ &72{,}910\div\purpleC{10^3} = 72{,}910\div\purpleC {10\div10\div10}\\\\ &72{,}910\div\maroonD{10^4} = 72{,}910\div\maroonD {10\div10\div10\div10} \end{align}$
Dividing by ${10}$ moves every digit one place to the right.    Drag the dot all the way to the right.    [[☃ interaction 1]]
So, if we divide by ${10}$ $\greenD{\text{two}}$ times, we move every digit **$\greenD{\text{two}}$ places to the right.**
Here are the completed equations:  $\begin{align} &72{,}910\div 10^2 =729.1\\\\ &72{,}910\div 10^3 =72.91\\\\ &72{,}910\div 10^4 =7.291 \end{align}$

###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$
$\begin{align} 9.1\times &\blueD{10^2} \\\\ 9.1\times  &\blueD{10\times10} \\\\ 9.1\div &\blueD{10^2} \\\\ 9.1\div  &\blueD{10\div10}   \end{align}$
Multiplying by ${10}$ moves every digit one place to the left.    So, multiplying by ${10}$ $\blueD{\text{two}}$ times, moves every digit **$\blueD{\text{two}}$ places to the left.**
Drag the dot all the way to the right.   [[☃ interaction 2]]    *Another way to think about this is that the decimal moves two places to the right.*
Dividing by $10$ moves every digit one place to the right.  So, dividing by ${10}$ $\blueD{\text{two}}$ times, moves every digit **$\blueD{\text{two}}$ places to the right.**
Drag the dot all the way to the right.   [[☃ interaction 2]]
Here are the completed equations:  $\begin{align} &9.1 \times 10^2=910 \\\\ &9.1 \div 10^2=0.091 \end{align}$

###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$
$\begin{align}  6\times &\blueD{10^2} \\\\ 6\times  &\blueD{10\times10}\\\\ 6\div &\blueD{10^2} \\\\ 6\div  &\blueD{10\div10} \end{align}$
Multiplying by ${10}$ moves every digit one place to the left.    So, multiplying by ${10}$ $\blueD{\text{two}}$ times, moves every digit **$\blueD{\text{two}}$ places to the left.**
Drag the dot all the way to the right.  [[☃ interaction 2]]  *Another way to think about this is that the decimal moves two places to the right.*
Dividing by $10$ moves every digit one place to the right.  So, dividing by ${10}$ $\blueD{\text{two}}$ times, moves every digit **$\blueD{\text{two}}$ places to the right.**
Drag the dot all the way to the right.  [[☃ interaction 3]]
Here are the completed equations:  $\begin{align} &1{,}615 \times 10^2 = 161{,}500\\\\ &1{,}615 \div 10^2= 16.15 \end{align}$

###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$
$\begin{align} 3.7\times &\blueD{10^1} \\\\ 3.7\times  &\blueD{10} \\\\ 3.7\div &\blueD{10^1} \\\\ 3.7\div  &\blueD{10}   \end{align}$

Multiplying by ${10}$ moves every digit one place to the left.    Drag the dot all the way to the right.   [[☃ interaction 2]]    *Another way to think about this is that the decimal moves one place to the right.*
Dividing by $10$ moves every digit one place to the right.  Drag the dot all the way to the right.   [[☃ interaction 2]]
Here are the completed equations:  $\begin{align} &3.7 \times 10^1=37\\\\ &3.7 \div 10^1=0.37 \end{align}$

###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$
$\begin{align}  &854\times \blueD{10^3} \\\\ &854\times  \blueD{10\times10\times10} \\\\ &854\div \blueD{10^3} \\\\ &854\div  \blueD{10\div10\div10}   \end{align}$
Multiplying by ${10}$ moves every digit one place to the left.    So, multiplying by ${10}$ $\blueD{\text{three}}$ times, moves every digit **$\blueD{\text{three}}$ places to the left.**
Drag the dot all the way to the right.  [[☃ interaction 2]]  *Another way to think about this is that the decimal moves three places to the right.*
Dividing by $10$ moves every digit one place to the right.  So, dividing by ${10}$ $\blueD{\text{three}}$ times, moves every digit **$\blueD{\text{three}}$ places to the right.**
Drag the dot all the way to the right.  [[☃ interaction 2]]
Here are the completed equations:  $\begin{align} &854 \times 10^3=854{,}000\\\\  &854 \div 10^3=0.854 \end{align}$

question.content: **Arrange the cards below to show the solution to $40.091 \times 10^3$.**

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$
$\begin{align}  &40.091\times \blueD{10^3} \\\\ &40.091\times  \blueD{10\times10\times10}   \end{align}$
Multiplying by ${10}$ moves every digit one place to the left.    So, multiplying by ${10}$ $\blueD{\text{three}}$ times, moves every digit **$\blueD{\text{three}}$ places to the left.**
Drag the dot all the way to the right.  [[☃ interaction 2]]

question.content: **Arrange the cards below to show the solution to $88\div 10^1$.**

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$
$\begin{align}  88\div &\blueD{10^1} \\\\ 88\div  &\blueD{10}   \end{align}$
Dividing by ${10}$ moves every digit one place to the right.    Drag the dot all the way to the right.  [[☃ interaction 2]]

question.content: **Arrange the cards below to show the solution to $709\div 10^2$.**

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$
$\begin{align}  709\div &\blueD{10^2} \\\\ 709\div  &\blueD{10}\div  \blueD{10}   \end{align}$
Dividing by ${10}$ moves every digit one place to the right.    Drag the dot all the way to the right.  [[☃ interaction 2]]

question.content: **Arrange the cards below to show the solution to $59.303 \times 10^2$.**

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$
$\begin{align}  59.303\times &\blueD{10^2} \\\\ 59.303\times  &\blueD{10\times10}   \end{align}$
Multiplying by ${10}$ moves every digit one place to the left.    So, multiplying by ${10}$ $\blueD{\text{two}}$ times, moves every digit **$\blueD{\text{two}}$ places to the left.**
Drag the dot all the way to the right.  [[☃ interaction 2]]

question.content: **Arrange the cards below to show the solution to $77{,}361 \div 10^3$.**

hints.content: ###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$
$\begin{align}  &77{,}361\div \blueD{10^3} \\\\ &77{,}361\div  \blueD{10\div10\div10}   \end{align}$
Dividing by ${10}$ moves every digit one place to the right.    So, dividing by ${10}$ $\blueD{\text{three}}$ times, moves every digit **$\blueD{\text{three}}$ places to the right.**
Drag the dot all the way to the right.  [[☃ interaction 3]]

###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$
Multiplying by ${10}$ moves every digit one place to the left.  Multiplying by a power of $10^\heartsuit$ moves every digit $\heartsuit$ places to the left.

Number | Hundred thousands | Ten thousands | Thousands | $,$ | Hundreds | Tens | Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $411.92$ |$\blueD{\leftarrow}$ | $\blueD{\leftarrow}$ | $\blueD{\leftarrow}$ || $4$ | $1$ | $1$ | $.$ | $9$ | $2$ $411{,}920$ | $4$ | $1$ | $1$ | $,$ | $9$ | $2$ | $0$ |||  The digits in $411.92$ moved $3$ places to the left. So we multiplied $411.92$ by $3$ factors of $10$.  $\begin{align} 411.92 \blueD{\times10 \times 10 \times 10} &=411{,}920 \\\\ 411.92 \blueD{\times10^3} &= 411{,}920 \end{align}$

Number | Ten thousands | Thousands | $,$ | Hundreds | Tens | Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $411.92$ |$\maroonD{\leftarrow}$ | $\maroonD{\leftarrow}$ || $4$ | $1$ | $1$ | $.$ | $9$ | $2$ $41{,}192$ | $4$ | $1$ | $,$ | $1$ | $9$ | $2$ | ||  The digits in $411.92$ moved $2$ places to the left. So we multiplied $411.92$ by $2$ factors of $10$.  $\begin{align} 411.92 \maroonD{\times10 \times 10} &=41{,}192 \\\\ 411.92 \maroonD{\times10^2} &= 41{,}192 \end{align}$

Number | Thousands | $,$ | Hundreds | Tens | Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $411.92$ |$\purpleC{\leftarrow}$ || $4$ | $1$ | $1$ | $.$ | $9$ | $2$ $4{,}119.2$ | $4$ | $,$ | $1$ | $1$ | $9$ | $.$ | $2$ |   The digits in $411.92$ moved $1$ place to the left. So we multiplied $411.92$ by $1$ factor of $10$.  $\begin{align} 411.92 \purpleC{\times10} &=4{,}119.2 \\\\ 411.92 \purpleC{\times10^1} &= 4{,}119.2 \end{align}$
Here are the completed equations.  $\begin{align} 411.92 \blueD{\times10^3} &= 411{,}920\\\\ 411.92 \maroonD{\times10^2} &= 41{,}192 \\\\ 411.92 \purpleC{\times10^1} &= 4{,}119.2 \end{align}$

###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$
Multiplying by ${10}$ moves every digit one place to the left.  Multiplying by a power of $10^\heartsuit$ moves every digit $\heartsuit$ places to the left.

Number | Thousands | $,$ | Hundreds | Tens | Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $63.85$ |$\purpleC{\leftarrow}$ || $\purpleC{\leftarrow}$ | $6$ | $3$ | $.$ | $8$ | $5$ $6{,}385$ | $6$ | $,$ | $3$ | $8$ | $5$ |  |  |   The digits in $63.85$ moved $2$ places to the left. So we multiplied $63.85$ by $2$ factors of $10$.  $\begin{align} 63.85 \purpleC{\times10\times10} &=6{,}385 \\\\ 63.85 \purpleC{\times10^2} &= 6{,}385 \end{align}$

Number | Ten thousands | Thousands | $,$ | Hundreds | Tens | Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $63.85$ |$\maroonD{\leftarrow}$ | $\maroonD{\leftarrow}$ || $\maroonD{\leftarrow}$ | $6$ | $3$ | $.$ | $8$ | $5$ $63{,}850$ | $6$ | $3$ | $,$ | $8$ | $5$ | $0$ | ||  The digits in $63.85$ moved $3$ places to the left. So we multiplied $63.85$ by $3$ factors of $10$.  $\begin{align} 63.85 \maroonD{\times10 \times 10\times 10} &=63{,}850 \\\\ 63.85 \maroonD{\times10^3} &= 63{,}850 \end{align}$

Number | Hundred thousands | Ten thousands | Thousands | $,$ | Hundreds | Tens | Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $63.85$ |$\blueD{\leftarrow}$ | $\blueD{\leftarrow}$ | $\blueD{\leftarrow}$ || $\blueD{\leftarrow}$ | $6$ | $3$ | $.$ | $8$ | $5$ $638{,}500$ | $6$ | $3$ | $8$ | $,$ | $5$ | $0$ | $0$ |||  The digits in $63.85$ moved $4$ places to the left. So we multiplied $63.85$ by $4$ factors of $10$.  $\begin{align} 63.85 \blueD{\times10 \times 10 \times 10\times 10} &=638{,}500 \\\\ 63.85\blueD{\times10^4} &= 638{,}500 \end{align}$
Here are the completed equations.  $\begin{align} 63.85 \purpleC{\times10^2} &= 6{,}385\\\\ 63.85 \maroonD{\times10^3} &= 63{,}850 \\\\ 63.85 \blueD{\times10^4} &= 638{,}500 \end{align}$

###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$
Dividing by ${10}$ moves every digit one place to the right.  Dividing by a power of $10^\heartsuit$ moves every digit $\heartsuit$ places to the right.

Number | Hundred thousands | Ten thousands | Thousands | $,$ | Hundreds | Tens | Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: $720{,}800$ | $7$ | $2$ | $0$ | $,$ | $8$ | $0$ | $0$ |||| $7.208 $ |$\blueD{\rightarrow}$ | $\blueD{\rightarrow}$ | $\blueD{\rightarrow}$ || $\blueD{\rightarrow}$ | $\blueD{\rightarrow}$ | $7$ | $.$ | $2$ | $0$| $8$  The digits in $720{,}800$ moved $5$ places to the right. So we divided $720{,}800$ by $5$ divisors of $10$.  $\begin{align} 720{,}800  \blueD{\div 10 \div 10 \div 10\div 10\div 10} &=7.208 \\\\ 720{,}800 \blueD{\div 10^5} &= 7.208 \end{align}$

Number | Hundred thousands | Ten thousands | Thousands | $,$ | Hundreds | Tens | Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:  $720{,}800$ | $7$ | $2$ | $0$ | $,$ | $8$ | $0$ | $0$ ||| $72.08 $ | $\maroonD{\rightarrow}$ | $\maroonD{\rightarrow}$ | $\maroonD{\rightarrow}$ || $\maroonD{\rightarrow}$ | $7$ | $2$ | $.$ | $0$| $8$  The digits in $720{,}800$ moved $4$ places to the right. So we divided $720{,}800$ by $4$ divisors of $10$.  $\begin{align} 720{,}800  \maroonD{\div 10 \div 10\div 10\div 10} &=72.08 \\\\ 720{,}800 \maroonD{\div 10^4} &= 72.08 \end{align}$

Number | Hundred thousands | Ten thousands | Thousands | $,$ | Hundreds | Tens | Ones | $.$ | Tenths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:  $720{,}800$ | $7$ | $2$ | $0$ | $,$ | $8$ | $0$ | $0$ || $720.8 $ | $\purpleC{\rightarrow}$ | $\purpleC{\rightarrow}$ | $\purpleC{\rightarrow}$ || $7$ | $2$ | $0$| $.$ | $8$  The digits in $720{,}800$ moved $3$ places to the right. So we divided $720{,}800$ by $3$ divisors of $10$.  $\begin{align} 720{,}800  \purpleC{\div 10\div 10\div 10} &=720.8 \\\\ 720{,}800 \purpleC{\div 10^3} &= 720.8 \end{align}$
Here are the completed equations.  $\begin{align} 720{,}800 \div \blueD{10^5}&=7.208\\\\ 720{,}800 \div \maroonD{10^4}&=72.08\\\\ 720{,}800 \div \purpleC{10^3}&=720.8 \end{align}$

###What is a power?  A power is a shortcut way of writing repeated multiplication.  $\redD{\text{base}}\rightarrow\redD{a}^{\purpleD{b}\leftarrow\purpleD{\text{exponent}}}$  We mean "$\purpleD{b}$ factors of $\red{a}$."   For example:  $\redD{10}^\purpleD{3}=\underbrace{\redD{10}\times \redD{10}\times \redD{10}}_{\purpleD{3\text{ factors}}}$
Dividing by ${10}$ moves every digit one place to the right.  Dividing by a power of $10^\heartsuit$ moves every digit $\heartsuit$ places to the right.

Number | Hundreds | Tens | Ones | $.$ | Tenths |  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: |  $624$ | $6$ | $2$ | $4$ | | $62.4 $ | $\blueD{\rightarrow}$ |$6$ | $2$ | $.$ | $4$  The digits in $624$ moved $1$ place to the right. So we divided $624$ by $1$ divisor of $10$.  $\begin{align} 624  \blueD{\div 10} &=62.4 \\\\ 624 \blueD{\div 10^1} &= 62.4 \end{align}$

Number | Hundreds | Tens | Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths  :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:  $624$ | $6$ | $2$ | $4$ | || $6.24 $ | $\maroonD{\rightarrow}$ | $\maroonD{\rightarrow}$ |$6$ | $.$ | $2$ | $4$  The digits in $624$ moved $2$ places to the right. So we divided $624$ by $2$ divisors of $10$.  $\begin{align} 624  \maroonD{\div 10\div 10} &=6.24 \\\\ 624 \maroonD{\div 10^2} &= 6.24 \end{align}$

Number | Hundreds | Tens | Ones | $.$ | Tenths | Hundredths | Thousandths :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-: | :-:  $624$ | $6$ | $2$ | $4$ | |||  $0.624 $ | $\purpleC{\rightarrow}$ | $\purpleC{\rightarrow}$ | $\purpleC{\rightarrow}$ |$.$ | $6$ | $2$ | $4$  The digits in $624$ moved $3$ places to the right. So we divided $624$ by $3$ divisors of $10$.  $\begin{align} 624  \purpleC{\div 10\div 10\div 10} &=0.624 \\\\ 624 \purpleC{\div 10^3} &= 0.624 \end{align}$
Here are the completed equations.  $\begin{align} 624 \div \blueD{10^1}&=62.4\\\\ 624 \div \maroonD{10^2}&=6.24\\\\ 624 \div \purpleC{10^3}&=0.624 \end{align}$
